questions.question: Which of the following is called "the window of limbic system" ?
questions.explanation: The amygdala has been called the "window" through which the limbic system sees the place of theperson in the world.The amygdala receives neuronal signals from all portions of the limbic cortex, as well as from theneocortex of the temporal, parietal, and occipital lobes, especially from the auditory and visualassociation areas.Components of the limbic system•The term limbic lobe, or limbic system, is applied to the part of the brain that consists of a rim ofcortical tissue around the hilum of the cerebral hemisphere and a group of associated deepstructures the amygdala, the hippocampus, and the septal nuclei.• The papez circuit is a closed neural circuitry that starts and ends in the hippocampus, whichforms the basal ganglia. It is also known as the medial limbic circuit. The components of papezcircuit are-Mnemonic-He Man Ate Cat• He-Hippocampus• Man-Mamillary body• Ate-Anterior thalamus•Cat-Cingulate gyrus

questions.question: Stimulation of which of the following regions promotes a 'sense of reward' in human beings?
questions.explanation: Major reward centres are located along the course of the medial forebrain bundle, especially in the lateral and ventromedial nuclei of the hypothalamus. Therefore, stimulation of those areas will promote a sense of reward. It is interesting to note that in the lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus, a weak stimulus produces a sense of pleasure whereas a strong stimulus produces rage. This phenomenon occurs in many areas where a weak stimulus produces a sense of reward while stronger ones produce a sense of punishment.

questions.question: In response to an increase in plasma osmolality, ADH is released in blood. Which of thefollowing sites contains the receptor to detect a change in plasma osmolality?
questions.explanation: Osmoreceptors that detect any change in plasma osmolality and control ADH secrection, arelocated in anterior hypothalamus.

questions.question: The main organ for biological clock is
questions.explanation: In the hypothalamus, the suprachiasmatic nucleus functions as the principal pacemaker, or timeclock, for circadian rhythms.The pacemaker receives input from the eyes and many other parts of the nervous system, andthese inputs mediate the effects exerted by the external environment (retinohypothalamic tract).One output of the pacemaker goes to the pineal gland, a gland within the brain that secretes thehormone melatonin. These neural signals cause the pineal gland to secrete melatonin duringdarkness but not during daylight.327

questions.question: Which of the following clinical features will be most likely seen in a patient with an anteriorhypothalamic lesion?
questions.explanation: Lesions involving the anterior and preoptic hypothalamic regions cause paradoxicalvasoconstriction, tachycardia, and hyperthermia.The anterior hypothalamus activates mechanisms of cooling the body when the temperatureincreases via the reflex response.Stimulation of the anterior hypothalamus causes cutaneous vasodilation and sweating, therebycooling the body. Lesions in this region cause hyperthermia, with rectal temperatures sometimesreaching 43°C (109.4°F).

questions.question: Diurnal variation of ACTH is controlled by which of the following regions?
questions.explanation: Diurnal variation of ACTH depends on the suprachiasmatic nucleus. The secretory rates of ACTH and cortisol are high in the early morning but low in the late evening. This effect results from a 24-hour cyclical alteration in the signals from the suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus that cause cortisol secretion. When a person changes daily sleeping habits, the cycle changes correspondingly.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a function of the categorical hemisphere?
questions.explanation: Functions of the categorical hemisphere are logical, analytical, sequential thinking, and verbaltasks, such as math, language forms, and philosophy.Human language functions depend more on one cerebral hemisphere than on the other. Thishemisphere is concerned with categorization and symbolization and has often been called thedominant hemisphere. However, the other hemisphere is specialized in the area of spatiotemporalrelations.The concept of "cerebral dominance" and a dominant and non-dominant hemisphere has beenreplaced by, one hemisphere for sequential-analytic processes (the categorical hemisphere) andone for visuospatial relations (the representational hemisphere).The representational cerebral hemisphere excels in nonlanguage skills, especially spatialperception, and artistic and musical talents.

questions.question: Lesions in which nucleus of the hypothalamus produce a voracious appetite and rage?

options.A: Upper region of the lateral hypothalamus

questions.explanation: A lesion in the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus, the satiety center, is responsible for producing a voracious appetite and rage. Lesions in the upper region of the lateral hypothalamus produce a profound loss of appetite.
